name: NPR
text:
James Hamblin hasn't showered in five years — and he's tired of being asked if he's smelly.

The physician and health reporter details the benefits and social dynamics of showering less in his new book, "Clean." https://t.co/Zl5EL1MLRE

name: NPR
text:
"Hench," the first novel from Natalie Zina Walschots, is an engrossing take on the superheroic.

The story examines what happens when the ability to calculate the human cost of disaster is coupled with a superhuman ability to organize and manipulate data. https://t.co/vpjBpmvVVh

name: NPR
text: Some two dozen states saw new COVID-19 cases continue to rise this past week, pushing the total number of U.S. cases to more than 7 million. https://t.co/MP2mCcRl2d

name: NPR
text: Weeks after a heatwave intensified devastating wildfires burning throughout California, crews are bracing for weekend weather conditions expected to hamper containment efforts. https://t.co/HiEtdNHDB8

name: NPR
text: President Trump’s extension of an existing offshore drilling moratorium in the Gulf of Mexico stands in contrast to his administration's record of supporting oil and gas production and rolling back rules on greenhouse gas emissions. https://t.co/QBf7UPSdsE

name: NPR
text: From NPR Music's Tiny Desk (home) concerts, we bring you Yo-Yo Ma, arguably the best known cellist in the world and the world-class musical ensemble known as Goat Rodeo, he first assembled nearly a decade ago. https://t.co/oSBZVXzsk6

name: NPR
text:
NPR Music's canon of Southern rap is an enthusiastic celebration that recenters the South as a creative center in hip-hop. It includes 130 albums, songs and mixtapes that together represent a cultural history of Southern rap, told on its own terms.
https://t.co/A110rSAaW0

name: NPR
text: During this pandemic, are you reading books that help you escape from reality, or connect you to it? African American literature professor Farah Jasmine Griffin's reading list includes novels that explore the beauty of life without ignoring its harshness. https://t.co/PSmsIrTcoJ

name: NPR
text:
When Elisabeth Thomas wrote "Catherine House," she wasn't expecting the story to feel quite so relevant to the events of 2020.

Set in a cult-like college, the mood is a familiar "dread mixed with nostalgia." https://t.co/OJ2yHtJwS1

name: NPR
text:
When you first start dating someone new, you usually consider their hobbies, common interests and politics to figure out if you're a good match.

Now you need to have the "COVID talk." https://t.co/h7vYBz25UU

name: NPR
text:
Anthony Bottom, 68, now called Jalil Muntaqim, is going home on parole after decades in jail for killing two NYPD officers in 1971. He’s at the center of a debate over elderly inmates convicted of violent crimes. Reform advocates say most should be freed.
https://t.co/zQU9HES8Yc

name: NPR
text:
"Bunheads" is Misty Copeland's second book for children. It's a semi-autographical version of her own childhood performance of "Coppélia" that our reviewer says will keep your kids who love dance going until classes come back.
https://t.co/1ehtDQxjJX

name: NPR
text:
Joe Biden implored Senate Republicans to wait on Trump's Supreme Court nominee until after the presidential election.

"Just because you have the power to do something doesn't absolve you of your responsibility to do right by the American people," he said.
https://t.co/CTSswfNkeE

name: NPR
text:
President Trump's new anti-drilling stance is a departure from his sustained willingness to explore domestic sources of energy. Some have questioned the sincerity of the move this close to the presidential election.
https://t.co/2tueb1MO2d

name: NPR
text:
1 in 5 Americans is spending more money now than they were before the pandemic, a recent survey finds — and many attribute this to stress-spending or comfort shopping.

That's OK, one financial expert says, as long as you’re sticking to a savings plan.
https://t.co/aq0gxX9tcw

name: NPR
text:
More than half of the people on federal death row are people of color, a new study finds. The victim’s race also matters a lot, an advocate notes: 

Defendants who kill white people are 17 times more likely to be executed.
 https://t.co/nvAchSGw3P
